questions.question: Which ancient ruin in the Middle East is known as the 'rose-red city half as old as time' and became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985?
questions.context: Famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system, this site was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom around the 4th century BC.

questions.question: Which modern architectural marvel located on the Arabian Peninsula is known for its sail-like design and stands as one of the world's tallest hotels?
questions.context: Opened in December 1999, this hotel is built on an artificial island and symbolizes Dubai's opulence and architectural innovation.

questions.question: At which historical battle site in Europe was Napoleon Bonaparte decisively defeated, marking the end of the Napoleonic Wars?
questions.context: Fought on June 18, 1815, this site witnessed the final defeat of Napoleon by the Seventh Coalition led by the Duke of Wellington.

questions.question: Which famous museum, located in East Asia, houses over 700,000 works of art and artifacts, and served as the imperial palace for nearly 500 years?
questions.context: Known as the Forbidden City, this museum in Beijing was home to Chinese emperors from the Ming to the end of the Qing dynasty.

questions.question: Which space exploration site located in North America was the launching site for the first humans on the Moon?
questions.context: Since 1968, this site has been NASA's primary launch center, notably launching Apollo 11 in 1969, which carried Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin to the Moon.
